steps.title: Cut a piece of cardboard into a rectangle.
steps.content: Cut a piece of cardboard into a rectangle. Roughly 12 inches (30 cm) by 6 inches should be fine. Make sure this is a heavier piece of cardboard, like from a packing box. If the cardboard is too light it will buckle when you wrap the lights around them.

steps.title: Cut a notch in one side of the cardboard.
steps.content: Cut a notch in one side of the cardboard. This should be big enough to tuck one end of the lights into. It doesn't matter if the notch is on the length or width side- this method will work either way.

steps.title: Wrap the lights around the rectangle.
steps.content: Wrap the lights around the rectangle. Do this neatly, working from one side to the other as needed. This will make unwrapping them much easier next year.

steps.title: Cut another notch wherever the other end of the lights is when you're done.
steps.content: Cut another notch wherever the other end of the lights is when you're done. Tuck the end into this notch just like you did with the first one.

steps.title: Wrap tissue paper around the lights.
steps.content: Wrap tissue paper around the lights. To protect the lights, wrap a layer or two of tissue paper around the cardboard. This will help protect them while they're in storage.

steps.title: Get an empty can of Pringles.
steps.content: Get an empty can of Pringles. Make sure you rinse out the inside of the tube- this isn't to protect your lights, but if there are crumbs left inside it could attract bugs to your storage area. As an alternative, you could also use the cardboard tube from a paper towel roll for this method. The steps will be the same, except you won't be placing a lid on the cardboard tube.

steps.title: Cut a slit in the top of the can.
steps.content: Cut a slit in the top of the can. Using a pair of heavy scissors, cut a vertical slit on the top of the can. The slit should be about an inch long.

steps.title: Slip one end of the lights into the slit.
steps.content: Slip one end of the lights into the slit. You can widen the slit with further cutting if the wire from the lights won't fit.

steps.title: Wrap the lights around the can.
steps.content: Wrap the lights around the can. Work your way down to the bottom of the can, then go back up to the top. Tuck the end of the lights into the same slit at the top of the can. This should leave you with the lights wrapped around the can with both ends resting in the slit on top.

steps.title: Place the lid on the Pringles can.
steps.content: Place the lid on the Pringles can. This will prevent the ends from slipping out of the slit and unraveling your lights during storage.

steps.title: Wrap the can in tissue paper.
steps.content: Wrap the can in tissue paper. To protect the lights during storage, you can wrap a few layers of tissue paper around the can. This should be done especially if you're placing the lights in a box with other items.

steps.title: Get a plastic hanger.
steps.content: Get a plastic hanger. Ideally, the hanger will have a little hook on each side of the body. You can still use this method if you hanger doesn't have hooks, but the hooks will make wrapping the lights much easier.

steps.title: Tuck one end of the lights into one of the hooks.
steps.content: Tuck one end of the lights into one of the hooks. [1] X Research source If your hanger doesn't have hooks, you can just tie the end to the body of the hanger.

steps.title: Wrap the lights around the outside of the hanger.
steps.content: Wrap the lights around the outside of the hanger. Gradually work your way to the other side of the hanger, then work back to the original side. You'll probably have to do this a few times to get the whole string on the hanger.

steps.title: Tuck the remaining end into the other hook.
steps.content: Tuck the remaining end into the other hook. Make sure you leave enough string at the end to reach the last hook. [2] X Research source If there isn't enough room or your hanger doesn't have hooks, just tuck the end in between the strands of lights.

steps.title: Store the hanger.
steps.content: Store the hanger. You can either place the lights in a box, or, since this is a hanger, you can hang it conveniently out of the way until next Christmas. If storing with other items, make sure to wrap the hanger in tissue paper for protection.

steps.title: Get a power cord holder.
steps.content: Get a power cord holder. These are available at most hardware store. There are several different kinds. You'll want a larger one designed for heavy outdoor electrical cords.

steps.title: Insert the lights into the cord holder and wind them up.
steps.content: Insert the lights into the cord holder and wind them up. Do this carefully to make sure you don't break any lights.

steps.title: Plug in more lights if you have them.
steps.content: Plug in more lights if you have them. The good thing about this method is that you can put multiple strands of lights into the same place. Just plug the new set of lights into the end of the old one and keep winding as long as you have room on the holder.

steps.title: Store the lights until next year.
steps.content: Store the lights until next year. You can place the power cord holder on a shelf, in a box, or hang it up if it has a hook.

steps.title: Pinch the second light of the strand between your index finger and thumb.
steps.content: Pinch the second light of the strand between your index finger and thumb. This should cause the first and third lights to fall next to each other in your palm. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Pull the fourth light up and pinch it next to the second one.
steps.content: Pull the fourth light up and pinch it next to the second one. Now, the first, third, and fifth lights should be in your palm.

steps.title: Continue matching the even lights to the top of your hand and the odd lights at the bottom.
steps.content: Continue matching the even lights to the top of your hand and the odd lights at the bottom. Keeping this sequence going should keep the lights in an even pattern that will prevent tangling. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Wrap the remaining cord around the bunch and plug the two sides in.
steps.content: Wrap the remaining cord around the bunch and plug the two sides in. When you're done wrapping, you should have a tight bunch of lights and the two plugs remaining. Wrap the small sections attached to the plugs around the bunch to keep it together. Then plug them into each other and you're all done. [5] X Research source
